text: in 2008 and 2009 we basically handed the
Iraqis a different kind of future on a
silver platter a country that was
fundamentally stable where the security
situation was under control and where
there was at least the foundations of a
democracy a multi-ethnic democracy but
two things have happened subsequently
one is in the last couple of years Prime
Minister Maliki has has been as
antagonistic to the Sunnis in Iraq as he
could be he's tried to arrest his Sunni
vice president Hacha me he's tried to
arrest other Sunni officials he's not
done anything to help the Sunnis in
Anbar province so a lot of the tribes in
the Anbar figure what's in it for us in
the government in Baghdad know you till
I don't know let me continue the
question is whether this has whether
what has happened in Fallujah and Ramadi
has served as a wake-up call to Maliki
that he has to reach out to the Sunnis
there are some signs that he is
beginning to do that when we can we'll
just have to keep our fingers crossed
but the other factor has been the civil
war in Syria and the spillover of that
conflict into Iraq and in into western
Iraq malachy couldn't do much about that
but but I think that these two things
have created the circumstances we're
saying the good news is we are not yet
seeing the re-emergence of the Shia
extremists militias like the jay shah
Mahdi and others should the United
States government now be providing
al-maliki with Hellfire missiles drones
and the scale of military support that
he says he needs to vanquish al Qaeda I
think yes but it needs to be conditioned
on Maliki reaching out to the Sunnis and
trying much harder to make them an
integral part of the Iraqi government
and Iraqi society
